data.author: Will Eccles

changelog.release_notes: First release! Enjoy!

data.description:
MLA is a watch face that brings you back to your days of writing essays in school. It brings serif font to your watch, telling you what time it is and the state of your battery.

Battery states:
100% = "Full"
50-90% = "Good"
30-40% = "Low"
20% = "Charge"
10% or less = "CHARGE!"

Supports both the Pebble and the Pebble Time. Also supports 12 and 24-hour clocks.

latest_release.release_notes: First release! Enjoy!

data.description:
Divide is a simple, functional watch that shows the time and battery life. You can even customize your colors!

Battery life is shown as the bar at the bottom of the screen. It's light blue when charging, and the color changes as the battery percent goes down.

Supports both 24 and 12 hour clocks.

Yes, you read that right. You can now change the colors of the text, bar, and background! Have fun!

data.author: Oliver Merkel

changelog.release_notes:
Here the current Moon phase is shown with more convenience for observers of southern hemisphere.

If holding the Pebble watch parallel over ground and turning it so the hour hand is pointing towards the sun then top of the watch face will always point in north direction and bottom of watch face in south direction on southern hemisphere (Compass feature).

Mind the observer's orientation and location: The compass feature is basically depending on the user's (or better the observer's) orientation and position on Earth - respectively the latitude of the observing position. At higher latitudes the compass feature is easier to use and more fail safe. The Earth's orbital plane around the sun projected onto the celestial sphere is called ecliptic. The Earth's equatorial plane projected onto the celestial sphere is called celestial equator. The ecliptic and the celestial equator are oblique by an angle of approximately 23.5 degrees currently. This means that an observer standing at any position close to the Earth's equator will lack a preferred view during noon (close to standing directly perpendicular under the sun called the sun is in observer's zenith) to point the hour hand towards the sun holding the watch parallel over ground. Meaning the compass feature is either not working at observer positions with smaller latitudes or the compass feature is at least hard to apply.

Mind the difference of southern hemisphere and northern hemisphere: On northern hemisphere top of the watch face will indicate south direction while bottom of watch face is oriented north.

Additionally the current Moon phase is shown for southern hemisphere. Moon phase display is expected to work until end of Unix Time (overflow on Jan 19th, 2038 03:14:07 GMT) at least as implemented here. For simplicity the axis of the Moon is shown vertically on the watch face only.

Mind that observer will have a preferred viewing direction: The Moon's view on the sky might vary from upright vertical orientation being rotated by a certain amount of degrees depending on observer's latitude and the current position of the sun. Regarding the observer's location/latitude it shows itself close to upside down between both hemispheres in direct comparison. The inclination of the Moon's orbital plane towards the plane of the Earth's equator has an angle of approximately 5 degrees. For simplicity assume that the Moon's orbital plane equals the plane of the Earth's equator neglecting the about 5 degrees angle. Such that on northern hemisphere the Moon will always appear in south direction with an observer usually and conveniently looking southward. On southern hemisphere vice versa just the other way around. Due to symmetry reason with an observer being near equator there is less preference or convenience for choosing a observation direction. The orientation of the crescent Moon can simlpy be swapped by an upwards looking observer turning towards opposite direction then.

Anyway the Moon's crescent always points towards the sun.

data.description: Decelerate your day with a less stressful time display. Exact time is shown by analog hour hand only. Additional feature is the display of the current Moon phase. The watchface shows a single hour hand only. Midnight is on bottom of the clockface while Noon is indicated on top. One rotation of the hour hand takes a whole day. An indicator for the seconds is blinking on bottom of the watchface. If holding the Pebble watch parallel over ground and turning it so the hour hand is pointing towards the sun then top of the watch face will always point in north direction and bottom of watch face in south direction on southern hemisphere (Compass feature). Additionally the current Moon phase is shown with more convenience for observers of southern hemisphere. Moon phase display is expected to work until end of Unix Time (overflow on Jan 19th, 2038 03:14:07 GMT) at least as implemented here.

latest_release.release_notes:
Here the current Moon phase is shown with more convenience for observers of southern hemisphere.

If holding the Pebble watch parallel over ground and turning it so the hour hand is pointing towards the sun then top of the watch face will always point in north direction and bottom of watch face in south direction on southern hemisphere (Compass feature).

Mind the observer's orientation and location: The compass feature is basically depending on the user's (or better the observer's) orientation and position on Earth - respectively the latitude of the observing position. At higher latitudes the compass feature is easier to use and more fail safe. The Earth's orbital plane around the sun projected onto the celestial sphere is called ecliptic. The Earth's equatorial plane projected onto the celestial sphere is called celestial equator. The ecliptic and the celestial equator are oblique by an angle of approximately 23.5 degrees currently. This means that an observer standing at any position close to the Earth's equator will lack a preferred view during noon (close to standing directly perpendicular under the sun called the sun is in observer's zenith) to point the hour hand towards the sun holding the watch parallel over ground. Meaning the compass feature is either not working at observer positions with smaller latitudes or the compass feature is at least hard to apply.

Mind the difference of southern hemisphere and northern hemisphere: On northern hemisphere top of the watch face will indicate south direction while bottom of watch face is oriented north.

Additionally the current Moon phase is shown for southern hemisphere. Moon phase display is expected to work until end of Unix Time (overflow on Jan 19th, 2038 03:14:07 GMT) at least as implemented here. For simplicity the axis of the Moon is shown vertically on the watch face only.

Mind that observer will have a preferred viewing direction: The Moon's view on the sky might vary from upright vertical orientation being rotated by a certain amount of degrees depending on observer's latitude and the current position of the sun. Regarding the observer's location/latitude it shows itself close to upside down between both hemispheres in direct comparison. The inclination of the Moon's orbital plane towards the plane of the Earth's equator has an angle of approximately 5 degrees. For simplicity assume that the Moon's orbital plane equals the plane of the Earth's equator neglecting the about 5 degrees angle. Such that on northern hemisphere the Moon will always appear in south direction with an observer usually and conveniently looking southward. On southern hemisphere vice versa just the other way around. Due to symmetry reason with an observer being near equator there is less preference or convenience for choosing a observation direction. The orientation of the crescent Moon can simlpy be swapped by an upwards looking observer turning towards opposite direction then.

Anyway the Moon's crescent always points towards the sun.

data.title: GMT Explorer

data.author: Sam Jerichow
data.description:
Summary: Very low resolution numbers
Readability: medium
Examples: 04:36, 12:59, 18:25, 20:47
Warning: It's the same as the M version for original Pebbles. 

I like pixels so I developped a display, that shows time with low resolution numbers.

Imagine the classic 7-segment numbers you know from LCD displays. In this watchface, they are pixelated to the max, until they are almost unrecognizeable. Almost. The result is a set of numbers made of 2x3 pixels which are still distinguishable by the position and the brightness of their pixels. The rule is: the more lines are in that area, the stronger the pixel. Low resolution doesn't mean low quality. There are pixels everywhere these days. It's a cool artistic way to describe reality. 

Design / Programming / Copyright © 2012, 2015 Sam Jerichow

Again, thanks to Nev Rawlins for his support!
data.title: Pixel Intensity C

data.author: frogamic

changelog.release_notes: Fixed issue where the clock would advance twice when started under certain circumstances.

Changed colors.

data.description:
It's about time. Pebble Time. The color of this watchface changes to match your Pebble. This face is all about your time.
About time shows the time exactly as you need it, not a string of numbers to a precision you don't care about, but a concise readout that's always about right. Chances are if you had an analogue watch, you'd round the time to this accuracy anyway.

latest_release.release_notes: Fixed issue where the clock would advance twice when started under certain circumstances.

data.author: finebyte

changelog.release_notes: Update for Diorite w HRM

Requires Glance Android 0.19 Newer Pebbles Only: - Increased number of layers for Custom Layouts (EXPERIMENTAL) - Background Color for Custom Layouts -- Use the Star button on a layout to set a background color - Hour Offsets -- After a time format add +/-n for offset hours/minutes -- e.g. %R+1 or %I:%M+30 - Added Calorie based Pebble Health Fields - Added formatter (star button) to control weather image type -- (Black and white, colour, colour with border) All Pebbles: - Customise QuickLaunch Mapping -- When Glance is launched from QuickLaunch it can open a specific screen. - Added LECO font - Added temperature conversion functions F_TO_C C_TO_F K_TO_C K_TO_F -- e.g. #F_TO_C #TEMP_MAX would convert whatever comes from TEMP_MAX from Fahrenheit to Celsius - Added more location caching (potential fix to issues with Android 6 Doze/App Standby)
Bugfix disappearing layers on custom faces, InverterLayer bug
Partial fix for custom face issues
Various reliability improvements and bugfixes
Bugfixes
Added round compatibilty

Glance 2.2 for Android app 0.16
- Experimental Pin Support - add Stocks, UKTrains, RSS & JSON to your timeline!
- New default bg colour for Pebble Time
- Override bg and fg colors for defaults on Pebble Time
- New Colour weather icons for Pebble Time
Glance as a watchface - Experimental

data.author: Andrew Holmes

changelog.release_notes:
Thanks for all of the Hearts! 

* Added a static "at a glance" screen for when Jetman goes to sleep so that the time can easily be seen.
* Shake your watch to put it back into "play the game" mode.
* Reduced the timeout to sleep from 10 to 5 minutes.

Colours on Pebble Time are still a work in progress - can only check values in the emulator, so don't know how they look on a real watch.  Will update when my Time gets here.
Adding Universal version of Jetpac Time (working around App Store problem).
Creating Aplite only version to try to make App Store recognise that Jetpac Time is now universal.
Updated for Original Pebbles (Aplite)
Updated for Original Pebbles (Aplite)
Added support for Original Pebbles (Aplite)
Added a fix for tapping/shaking to wake up.  Thanks to Reddit user Woogal !

Initial release.
Let me know if there are problems.  I don't have a Pebble Time yet to test it against, so has only been run in the Emulator.

data.description:
A Jetpac inspired watchface for Pebble Time!

Watch Jetman fly around with his trusty Jetpac.  He's forever looking for the correct rocket parts to blast off to a new planet just like the one he's already on.

Every minute Jetman will destoy rocket parts that he doesn't like.
Every hour, he'll build his rocket and blast off.

Jetpac Time is battery friendly.  
After two minutes Jetman will stop flying around, and only shoot numbers when they should change.
After ten minutes, he'll go to sleep and the digits will change on their own. However, hourly animations will still run.
You can wake jetman by tapping your pebble. 

The number of lives remaining is your Pebble's battery status.

Jetpac Time is inspired by the Ultimate Play the Game's classic ZX Spectrum Jetpac game from 1983.

latest_release.release_notes:
Thanks for all of the Hearts! 

* Added a static "at a glance" screen for when Jetman goes to sleep so that the time can easily be seen.
* Shake your watch to put it back into "play the game" mode.
* Reduced the timeout to sleep from 10 to 5 minutes.

Colours on Pebble Time are still a work in progress - can only check values in the emulator, so don't know how they look on a real watch.  Will update when my Time gets here.

data.title: Jetpac Time

data.description:
Displays the time, no tricks.

data.author: Alex Wiebe

changelog.release_notes:
Well this is awkward - a major bug was causing double timezone conversions. That has hopefully been fixed....

As well, there is an issue of heavens-above being overwhelmed and instituting quotas. Not sure what they are at the moment. But trying to ensure I only make reasonable requests.

1 - Remove hourly updates
2 - put semaphore around sending request to ensure only a single request is sent
3 - fixed double UTC to Local Timezone conversion!

Added date to string.
Removed settings flag (shouldn't attempt a settings page)
Removed hourly refresh - try to reduce strain on heavens-above

Initial release.
Using current location, finds the next 4 flares of at least a 0 magnitude.
Every minute alternates between:
* text display of (local) time, azimuth (compass direction), altitude (how far to tilt head back) and magnitude (how bright - smaller is brighter)
* graphical map of the flares

Based idea and initial code base from "Iridium Forecast Clock" by Nikita Komarov.

data.description:
Displays next 4 visible Iridium flares (Magnitude 0 or brighter). Alternates between text display and graphical display.

4 1/2 minutes and 10 seconds before upcoming flare watch will give a little nudge to remind you to get in position/look up.

BTW, Iridium Flare data is coming from heavens-above.com. They are getting overwhelmed with all these 'smart' apps pinging and poking them. If you like this app, find a way to say thank you to h-a and send them some money or something.

latest_release.release_notes:
Well this is awkward - a major bug was causing double timezone conversions. That has hopefully been fixed....

As well, there is an issue of heavens-above being overwhelmed and instituting quotas. Not sure what they are at the moment. But trying to ensure I only make reasonable requests.

1 - Remove hourly updates
2 - put semaphore around sending request to ensure only a single request is sent
3 - fixed double UTC to Local Timezone conversion!

data.title: Iridium Flare Monitor

A simple circular watch. With hours, minutes and the month's day.

orange: 30%-40%

verde: 50% - 70%
naranja: 30% -40%
rojo: <30%

Right (blue bar) is your BlueTooth Connection.  It's lit up when connected and faded blue when not connected.

Hit the love button if you've got a popular spy theme going through your head now!

data.author: Sam Jerichow
data.description:
Summary: Minimalistic bars as numbers
Readability: medium
Examples: 04:36, 12:59, 18:25, 20:47

The red version was made for the Red Pebble Time. 

The Monolith display idea started with sketching for minimalistic numbers. I made these slim blocks with different lengths that form numbers in a new way. They look a bit like a barcode or some skyscraper lights. There are no horizontal elements but these numbers work just fine. 

Monolith is clean, solid, minimalistic, geeky and cool.

Design / Programming / Copyright © 2012, 2015 Sam Jerichow

data.description: A face based on my previous Back to Basics face. As the name implies, it shows a little less. A little less cluttered date, a little less advanced battery meter, and a little less weather info, because you can just look outside to see what the weather is, but not necessarily the temperature. Everything is shown at the center of the screen, with the time as the main focal point in an easily-seen typeface.

data.description: Crammed as much information as I could onto the watch face, and added many power management features.  The weather symbol next to the date is the current conditions. The 5 symbols along the bottom are the 5 day forecast starting with the forecast for the rest of today. Battery level and charge indicator. Tap events cause a weather update. Power saving mode, where if the watch is still for a while (such as when not attached to an arm) then still mode is entered and battery saving happens by not updating the weather every 15 minutes. When leaving still mode the weather is updated immediately. A weather update is never done when the last one was within 3 minutes. For temperatures, the trend up or down is also indicated. Time when the last weather update happened is shown. Reduced power consumption by not having a time and display update every second, now it is every minute and only switches to every second for 10 seconds following a weather update event. Quick vibrate on the hour and every 15 minutes. Wakes up and update on bringing the watch up to your face. This app is open source, and based on the great Futura Weather 2, but with many additional features and a completely redesigned display.

latest_release.release_notes: Removed the settings option which was just hanging. Will add some settings soon and re-enable it.

data.author: Chris Poole

changelog.release_notes:
-Improved stability and battery usage of weather 
-Added location confirmation after changing weather settings

-Fixed weather issues

Sorry for the delay everyone! My midterms really swamped me this semester!
As always, email me with any bugs or suggestions for current or new apps
Added option for vibrate on bluetooth disconnect (2 pulses)
Now supports Aplite! (stay tuned for the ability to invert the colors) Bug fixes include: Temperature over 100 units no longer overlaps with the date. Other minor tweaks and fixes.
Fixes weather not updating when sleep mode finishes, as well as other small fixes.

Included in V1.4:
• Added sleep hours! You can now select a time frame so the watch will not vibrate hourly and the weather fetching is stopped.
• Bug fixes for weather fetching (stay tuned for a better weather provider)
• Graphical bug fixes (date, fonts, etc.)
• Added option to disable battery meter
Fixed persistent lat/long coordinates

Updated in V1.2:
- Added color customization - background and font color can be chosen from any of the 64 colors on Pebble Time
- Added battery meter in center of watchface
- Manual location based on latitude/longitude
- Bug fixes (weather 'load' problem)
- Last fetched temperature is now stored in memory - if the temperature is newly fetched, it is shown in bold face
- Graphical tweaks

1. Block Time is now configurable! Choose between Celsius and Fahrenheit, pick a static weather location, and turn on/off hourly vibrate. Keep on the look out for more configuration options coming soon. 

2. Bluetooth status now shown in the center of the screen. Blue square represents an active bluetooth connection, red means that is is disconnected.

data.description:
A block-style watchface for Pebble Time and Time Steel inspired by /u/schamu on the Pebble subreddit. 

Features include:
• Support for both 12 and 24 hour time
• Day, date, and month
• Current temperature (Celsius or Fahrenheit) based on either current location, custom zip code, or lat/long coordinates
• Bluetooth connection status (blue square = connected, red = disconnected)
• Battery meter (updates every 10%, fully green when charging)
• Background and font color configuration - choose from any of the 64 colors available on Pebble Time
• Hourly vibrate option (see configuration page)
• Persistent storage of settings

Included in V1.4: 
• Added sleep hours! You can now select a time frame so the watch will not vibrate hourly and the weather fetching is stopped. 
• Bug fixes for weather fetching (stay tuned for a better weather provider) 
• Graphical bug fixes (date, fonts, etc.) 
• Added option to disable battery meter

Please contact me with suggestions or with found bugs!

Future updates include:
• Expanded weather detail screen
• Animations

latest_release.release_notes:
-Improved stability and battery usage of weather 
-Added location confirmation after changing weather settings

data.title: Block Time

data.description:
A fun, animated, easy to read watchface. Every minute the bubbles in the background pop, and a set of new ones appear (by default) in a new colour. Alternatively you can customsise the colour of the bubbles. Tapping or shaking the watch also triggers the animation.

Inspired by the red Pebble Time advertising images.

Includes configuration options for analog or digital display, and filled or hollow bubbles.

latest_release.release_notes: Updated to support Pebble Round, including addition of configuration options for an analog display style and filled bubbles.

data.title: Pop!

data.author: Sam Jerichow
data.description:
Summary: Color bars instead of numbers.
Readability: easy
Examples: 04:36, 12:59, 18:25, 20:47

This is another version of my original Spectrum. Gotta love those bars :) The Pi version has numbers below to help you read the time and actually to train you to read the other Spectrum versions.

Spectrum is a fun watchface with a scientific background. It started as binary idea. 1 = white and 0 = black. Once I had the basic shades for the basic numbers I thought, it would be interesting to give all the other numbers parts of the color spectrum. The cool thing is, the color spectrum can be divided into 8 distinguishable colors indeed! I'm using four long bars to tell the time. This is inspired by emission spectra of elements that get passed by light. The width of the bars increases by the usage of that digit. 

So basically, each number is a color. Sounds simple, but how do you learn which color belongs to which number? Make up a story. Red is love of two people. Orange three sounds like orange tree etc. The sillier the story, the easier to memorize. After a while you can read the watch faster while others just see wrist decoration.

Check out the color reference chart in the preview section and... enjoy!

Design / Programming / Copyright © 2012, 2015 Sam Jerichow
data.title: Spectrum Pi

data.author: Sam Jerichow
data.description:
Summary: Color bars instead of numbers.
Readability: hard
Examples: 04:36, 12:59, 18:25, 20:47

This is another version of my original Spectrum. Gotta love those bars :) Check out the Pi version with numbers!

Spectrum is a fun watchface with a scientific background. It started as binary idea. 1 = white and 0 = black. Once I had the basic shades for the basic numbers I thought, it would be interesting to give all the other numbers parts of the color spectrum. The cool thing is, the color spectrum can be divided into 8 distinguishable colors indeed! I'm using four long bars to tell the time. This is inspired by emission spectra of elements that get passed by light. The width of the bars increases by the usage of that digit. 

So basically, each number is a color. Sounds simple, but how do you learn which color belongs to which number? Make up a story. Red is love of two people. Orange three sounds like orange tree etc. The sillier the story, the easier to memorize. After a while you can read the watch faster while others just see wrist decoration.

I recommend  the color reference chart in the preview section. Good luck!

Design / Programming / Copyright © 2012, 2015 Sam Jerichow
data.title: Spectrum Gamma

data.description:
A cute animated dog for your pebble watch. It show the time 24h/12h and date with a cute dog running around to make you happy. The app only consume power when you are using Pebble watch and otherwise the dog is sleeping and preserve power. If you like the app please support it by contributing on valtiel.com. It will be very appreciated and you will support me in making more updates with new animations. 

Features: 
✔ Virtual pet and watch in a single app 
✔ Different animations and background events 
✔ Show date, time and battery status 
✔ Funny animations to watch and minimal battery use when inactive 
✔ More updates to come, follow on valtiel.com

Important note! The text "Valtiel.com" will disappear in the Pebble App if you add a user and contribute on valtiel.com  

If you love the watchface, please give it a <3 and follow the progress for next update at valtiel.com 
Thank you for using one of my Apps.

latest_release.release_notes: First release.

data.description:
The best watch face when you need glance of iPhone calendar's on your wrist.
Showing up to 4 upcoming events (update every 10 minutes). 
Weather and temperature of current location (don't forget to enable location in Smartwatch Pro) from http://openweathermap.org (update every 20 minutes).
Battery level with 10% increments and charging animation (animation stops when battery is completely full).

Other features:
Lost bluetooth connection warning (with vibration).
A lot of date and time format options. 
Show/hide All-day events, seconds, weather update status.

Feel free to comment, pass suggestions... and set Like :)

data.description:
Hour : Chevrons(1 to 12)
Minute : Address glyph Tau'ri(white colored)

CAUTION
This watchface is available on Pebble Time/Pebble Time Steel only.
Also this might be a battery hungry one due to animation.

hh:00 : Dial sequence (10 FPS)
to hh:38 : Event horizon (4 FPS)
hh:39 : Close wormhole (10 FPS)
to hh:59 : No animation (redraw once per one minute)

If you feel animations and vibrations are annoying, you can use the Iris with tapping your Pebble.
Additionally in case of under 10% battery charge, St@rgate cannot open/hold a wormhole due to an electric shortage.

data.description:
A stamp collection of timestamp.

- Setting: Weather temperature units (Celsius, Fahrenheit, Kelvin) 
- Setting: Vibes on phone disconnect  
- Setting: Day/Month order
- Time in 12h or 24h

- Multiple color themes: 
  + 9 color schemes (for Pebble Time) / 2 color schemes (for Pebble original) 
  + Random mode, color scheme changes every minute 
  + Color weather condition (smart and dynamic color scheme, check my COLOR WEATHER watchface for more information)

data.title: Timestamp!

data.author: Sam Jerichow
data.description:
Summary: Minimalistic bars as numbers
Readability: medium
Examples: 04:36, 12:59, 18:25, 20:47

The Monolith display idea started with sketching for minimalistic numbers. I made these slim blocks with different lengths that form numbers in a new way. They look a bit like a barcode or some skyscraper lights. There are no horizontal elements but these numbers work just fine. 

Monolith is pure, simple, minimalistic, geeky and stylish as well.

Design / Programming / Copyright © 2012, 2015 Sam Jerichow

Thanks Nev Rawlins for your help!
data.title: Monolith C

data.author: Yannick Breton

changelog.release_notes: Fixes an issue with year-month-day format in newest firmware.
Shifts the status bar down 1 pixel to deal with rounded corners of Pebble Time.
Updates the Pebble Time version with inverted colors to make the watch face more readable.
Performance enhancements.
Code optimization fixes. (Removed some mark_layer_dirty calls, some redundant status bar update calls).
Adjusted vertical alignment, fixed improper conversion of Celcius to Farenheit.
Added temperature (C/F) to upper status bar and location/country below ISO date. Fetches data from OpenWeatherMap on the hour.
Weekday display and bluetooth connectivity indicator fixes.
Fixes a bug with displaying the weekday.

data.description: Analog/digital watch face with status bar and ticking lower second bar. Vibrates on disconnect. Retrieves temperature in Celsius/Fahrenheit for current location from OpenWeatherMap. Temperature is displayed in upper status bar; location and country displayed below ISO date.

latest_release.release_notes: Fixes an issue with year-month-day format in newest firmware.

data.author: FG

changelog.release_notes:
v16.1:
Added pull request from Nerten for https://github.com/MarSoft/pebble-mss.
Pull request #1 "Prevent hourly vibes on quiet time".

v16.0:
 - MarSoft mod 1 included, which means AM and PM support for the sun rise and sun set times in 12h mode and unobstructed area support with fading. 
 - Changed red color at 20% battery on Diorite to white on black.
 - added some commented code for heart rate support, but this will not work yet. I don't know if I will add this support at any time.

For Aplite watches (first Pebble and Pebble Steel) no changes were made.

v15.7:
added pull request from github user guckuck:

Change color schema on critical battery level

Change the behavior on pebble 2 with black white display: Now the
colors will be inverted when battery level is <= 20%.

v15.6
 - Updated the java including style

- supports Platform Diorite (Pebble 2)
 - config page is now hosted via github

v15.3:
 - Weather icons also available at night. Moon phase automatically if no clouds.
 - Updated color of seconds and calendar week in profile 13.
 - Added option to disable temperature dependent colors of actual temperature.

v15.2:
 - bug fix for aplite version (memory issue): removed vibe on full charge completly because it was not working any more on SDK 3.
- Bug fix of Bluetooth vibration also coming on shaking.

v15.0:
 - updated UI on Platform Chalk (Pebble Time Round)
 - little bug fix
 - implemented color-profile cycling for easier reviewing

v15.0.1:
 - Weather update loop bug fix
 - Changed Health display with images

v15.0.2:
 - small color fix for health text
 - added up-down arrow to show if more or less than average health value was reached
 - changes in location setup:
    - new option to disable GPS at all (may fix some update lags)
    - changed warning color to black if the default location was used when no GPS position could be retrieved

v15.0.3:
 - solved 0:00:00 time but after settings changed to health displaymode

v14.7: 
 - solved some bugs in weather update

v14.6
 - changed some blue sky colors to a little bit darker ones
 - added health display (at the position of the time zone, configurable)

v14.5
 - solved issue with localtime which showed the sun set time sometimes in the main time and mixed hours/minutes afterwards.
 - increased timeout of location detection

v14.4:
 - changed vibe patterns and solved bug with vibe on start

v14.3:
 - fixed AM/PM/24H stuff

v14.2:
 - changed to FW 3.8.2 for all platforms
 - added option to never show moon phase

v13.0
 - centered the image on PTR (chalk)

v12.9
 - changed the way the time is being read from the firmware.

v12.8
 - bug fix with calendar week on Aplite platform.

data.description:
Seven Segment watchface which displays the follwing additional info:
 - time including seconds (sec. can be disabled or displayed on shaking)
 - weather (temperature/conditions/wind speed/pressure/humidity)
 - weather forecast: max/min temperature of next 24 hours
 - moon phase / weather condition icon
 - current location or configurable location
 - current time zone with name / UTC time
 - health status
 - calendar week
 - time since last weather update (or server update)
 - battery lifetime:
       - if charging/discharging: time since begin of charging/discharging
       - if full and plugged: last charging duration
       - colors to indicate state
 - background light (configurable)
 - Many colors profiles.
 - On Pebble Time, temperature has different colors for different temperatures

The weather info is downloaded from openweathermap.org using the detected location from the phone or a user specified one. If an error in automatic location detection occurs, the default location is used and the location field is marked red. Its also marked red if you leave an area around the manually setted location.

Please note, if light is switched on, the battery is draining very fast (only some hours). Displaying seconds allways limits the battery to about 6 days max.

latest_release.release_notes:
v16.1:
Added pull request from Nerten for https://github.com/MarSoft/pebble-mss.
Pull request #1 "Prevent hourly vibes on quiet time".

data.description:
Random poetry generator.
Most of the time it's nonsense and not formal but it makes something new to read when you are bored. 
Tap/shake the watch to renew the text. 
Am/pm mode only as military time don't suits  poetry. 
No network usage text is generated by the watch. 
Code is optimize to reduce cpu usage. 

I made it three years ago, I never had the time to publish it. It was adapted from a forth language source it perhaps originates from the 80's.

data.description:
A minimal and efficient watchface for Pebble and Pebble Steel.

"Clean" consists of a digital LCD clock and date, and a battery meter. It is designed to have minimal impact on power and resources.

--- Changelog ---  

2 Jun 2015 (r1.4)
New Settings page! Minor bugfixes and improvements.

2 Jun 2015 (r1.3)
Minor memory bugfixes

2 Jun 2015 (r1.2)  
Added the ability to invert the colors of the watch face

latest_release.release_notes: BUGFIXES. OH GOD

data.title: Clean

data.author: Nicholas Currault
data.description:
For a classy touch to your watch, this face uses a "sweeping" second hand (one that moves continuously, rather than once per second).

It also features a number at 3 o'clock, which displays the day of the month.

The face updates every 50 milliseconds to achieve this effect, which may adversely affect battery life.
data.title: Classy Sweep
